section.title: Uniform Asymptotic Expansions for Large Parameter

para.sentence: Define \lambda=z/a,\eta=\left(2(\lambda-1-\ln\lambda)\right)^{1/2}, where the branch of the square root is continuous and satisfies \eta(\lambda)\sim\lambda-1 as \lambda\to 1.
Then \tfrac{1}{2}\eta^{2}=\lambda-1-\ln\lambda,\frac{\mathrm{d}\eta}{\mathrm{d}\lambda}=\frac{\lambda-1}{\lambda\eta}.

Also, denote P\left(a,z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(-\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)- S(a,\eta), Q\left(a,z\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)+S (a,\eta), \frac{e^{\pm\pi ia}}{2i\sin\left(\pi a\right)}Q\left(-a,ze^{\pm\pi i}\right)= \pm\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\pm i\eta\sqrt{a/2}\right)-iT(a,\eta), and z^{-a}\gamma^{*}\left(-a,-z\right)=\cos\left(\pi a\right)-2\sin\left(\pi a \right)\left(\frac{e^{\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{\pi}}F\left(\eta\sqrt{a/2} \right)+T(a,\eta)\right), where F\left(x\right) is Dawson’s integral; see §7.2(ii).

Then as a\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta(<\pi) , S(a,\eta)\sim\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty }c_{k}(\eta)a^{-k}, T(a,\eta)\sim\frac{e^{\frac{1}{2}a\eta^{2}}}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_{k}(\eta)(-a)^{-k}, in each case uniformly with respect to \lambda in the sector |\operatorname{ph}\lambda|\leq 2\pi-\delta ( <2\pi ).

With \mu=\lambda-1 , the coefficients c_{k}(\eta) are given by c_{0}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\mu}-\frac{1}{\eta},c_{1}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\eta^{3}}-\frac{1}{\mu^{3}}-\frac{1}{\mu^{2}}-\frac{1}{12 \mu}, c_{k}(\eta)=\frac{1}{\eta}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}\eta}c_{k-1}(\eta)+(-1)^ {k}\frac{g_{k}}{\mu}, if k=1,2,\dots, where g_{k} , k=0,1,2,\dots , are the coefficients that appear in the asymptotic expansion ( 5.11.3) of \Gamma\left(z\right).

The right-hand sides of equations (8.12.9), (8.12.10) have removable singularities at \eta=0 , and the Maclaurin series expansion of c_{k}(\eta) is given by c_{k}(\eta)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}d_{k,n}\eta^{n}, if |\eta|<2\sqrt{\pi}, where d_{0,0}=-\tfrac{1}{3} , d_{0,n}=(n+2)\alpha_{n+2}, if n\geq 1, //// d_{k,n}=(-1)^{k}g_{k}d_{0,n}+(n+2)d_{k-1,n+2}, if n\geq 0, k\geq 1, and \alpha_{3},\alpha_{4},\dots are defined by \lambda-1=\eta+\tfrac{1}{3}\eta^{2}+\sum_{n=3}^{\infty}\alpha_{n}\eta^{n}, if |\eta|<2\sqrt{\pi}.
For numerical values of d_{k,n} to 30D for k=0(1)9 and n=0(1)N_{k} , where N_{k}=28-4\left\lfloor k/2\right\rfloor , see DiDonato and Morris (1986).

Special cases are given by Q\left(a,a\right)\sim\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{ k}(0)a^{-k}, if |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta, \frac{e^{\pm\pi ia}}{2i\sin\left(\pi a\right)}Q\left(-a,ae^{\pm\pi i}\right) \sim\pm\frac{1}{2}-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2\pi a}}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{k}(0)(-a)^{-k}, if |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta, where c_{0}(0)=-\tfrac{1}{3},c_{1}(0)=-\tfrac{1}{540},c_{2}(0)=\tfrac{25}{6048},c_{3}(0)=\tfrac{101}{1\;55520},c_{4}(0)=-\tfrac{31\;84811}{36951\;55200},c_{5}(0)=-\tfrac{27\;45493}{81517\;36320}.
For error bounds for (8.12.7) see Paris (2002a).
For the asymptotic behavior of c_{k}(\eta) as k\to\infty seeDunster et al. (1998) and Olde Daalhuis (1998c).
The last reference also includes an exponentially-improved version (§2.11(iii)) of the expansions (8.12.4) and (8.12.7) for Q\left(a,z\right).

A different type of uniform expansion with coefficients that do not possess a removable singularity at z=a is given by \rselection{Q\left(a,z\right)\\ P\left(a,z\right)}\sim\frac{z^{a-\frac{1}{2}}e^{-z}}{\Gamma\left(a\right)}{ \left(d(\pm\chi)\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{A_{k}(\chi)}{z^{k/2}}\mp\sum_{k=1}^{ \infty}\frac{B_{k}(\chi)}{z^{k/2}}\right)}, for z\to\infty in \left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , with \Re(z-a)\leq 0 for P\left(a,z\right) and \Re(z-a)\geq 0 for Q\left(a,z\right).

Here \chi=(z-a)/\sqrt{z},d(\pm\chi)=\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{2}\pi}e^{\chi^{2}/2}\operatorname{erfc}\left(\pm \chi/\sqrt{2}\right), and A_{0}(\chi)=1,A_{1}(\chi)=\tfrac{1}{2}\chi+\tfrac{1}{6}\chi^{3},B_{1}(\chi)=\tfrac{1}{3}+\tfrac{1}{6}\chi^{2}.
Higher coefficients A_{k}(\chi) , B_{k}(\chi) , up to k=8 , are given inParis (2002b).
Lastly, a uniform approximation for \Gamma\left(a,ax\right) for large a , with error bounds, can be found in Dunster (1996a).
For other uniform asymptotic approximations of the incomplete gamma functionsin terms of the function \operatorname{erfc} see Paris (2002b) andDunster (1996a).
For asymptotic expansions, as a\to\infty , of the inverse function x=x(a,q) that satisfies the equation Q\left(a,x\right)=q see Temme (1992a).
These expansions involve the inverse error function \operatorname{inverfc}\left(x\right) (§7.17), and are uniform with respect to q\in[0,1].
As a special case, x(a,\tfrac{1}{2})\sim a-\tfrac{1}{3}+\tfrac{8}{405}a^{-1}+\tfrac{184}{25515}a^ {-2}+\tfrac{2248}{34\;44525}a^{-3}+\cdots, if a\to\infty.
